Graphical abstract Ce4+ & F− co-doping inhibits O2 release by regulating Co 3d–O 2p and accelerates Li+ transport and CeO2− x and CeOF heterostructure resist HF corrosion, improving the cycling performance of LiCoO2 exceeding 4.60 V. Lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO2) is proverbially employed as cathode materials of lithium-ion batteries attributed to the high theoretical capacity, and currently, it is developing towards higher cut-off voltages in the pursuit of higher energy density. However, it suffers from serious structural degradation and surface side reactions, in particular, at the voltage above 4.60 V, leading to rapid decay of the battery life. Taking into account the desirable oxygen buffering property and the fast ion mobility characteristic of cerium oxide fluoride, in this work, we prepared Ce & F co-modified LiCoO2 by using the precursors of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and NH4F, and evaluated the electrochemical performance under voltages exceeding 4.60 V. The results indicated that the modified samples have multiphase heterostructure of surface CeO2− x and unique CeOF solid solution phase. At 3.0–4.60 V and 25 °C, the preferred sample LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F has a high initial discharge specific capacity of 221.9 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C, with the retention of 80.3% and 89.6% after 300 cycles at 1 and 5 C, comparing with the pristine LCO (56.4% and 22.6%). And at 3.0–4.65 V, its retention is 64.0% after 300 cycles at 1 C, versus 8.5% of the pristine LCO. Through structural characterizations and DFT calculations, it suggests that Ce4+ & F− co-doping suppresses the H3 to H1/3 irreversible phase transition, stabilizes the lattice structure, and reduces the redox activity of the lattice oxygen by modulating the Co 3d–O 2p energy band, consequently improving the electrochemical performance of LiCoO2 at high voltages. Keywords LiCoO2 High-voltage electrochemical performance Ce4+ & F− co-doping Multiphase heterostructure DFT calculation 1 Introduction Lithium cobalt oxide LiCoO2 (LCO) occupies the majority of the market in computers, communications and consumer electronics (3C products) with high theoretical specific capacity (274 mA h g−1) and compaction density (4.2 g cm−3) [1–3]. In order to release higher capacities in smaller space conditions, it necessitates to develop high-performance LCO at higher voltages. Increasing the cut-off voltage is a valid strategy to achieve higher energy density for LCO, however, it suffers from the structural degradation and surface side reactions, in particular, when the voltage exceeds 4.60 V. Under high voltages, the H3H1/3O1 phase transition with the OCoO layer slipping generates internal stresses that destroy the structure [4]. In addition, due to the high covalency of CoO bonds, Co 3d and O 2p energy bands overlap resulting in the lattice oxygen involved in charge compensation at high voltages, inducing O2 release and Co dissolution [5,6], then accelerating the electrolyte decomposition, which will lead to severe structural degradation and rapid decay of capacity. To obtain higher electrochemical performance of LCO at high voltage, element dopants, involving metal cations Mg [7], Ti [8], Mn [9], Ba [10], Mo [11], Gd [12] and/or non-metal ions F [13], B [14], P [15] etc., have been studied besides the modification of surface coatings such as ZnO [16], CeO2 [17], LiF [18], AlF3 [19], CeP2O7 [20], Li2TiO3 [21], LiNbO3 [22], and so on. The rare earth element Cerium (Ce) has high charge and strong self-polarization characteristics, with the relatively large ionic radius (r Ce 4+ = 0.87 Å) [23,24]. Ning et al. [25] adopted density functional theory (DFT) calculations and reported Ce4+ doping can increase the volume of LiCoO2 and decrease the migration energy barrier of Li+. Hao et al. [26] prepared CeO2− x -coated and Ce4+-doped LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2, exhibiting increased rate performance with the retention of 80.3% at 8 C after 500 cycles in the range of 3.0–4.3 V (room temperature), comparing to 44.3% for the pristine cathode material. Fei et al. [27] prepared Mg2+ & Ce4+ co-doped LiCoO2 by solid phase method and it has a discharge specific capacity of 181.9 mA h g−1 at 1 C with the retention of 80.36% after 100 cycles at 3.0–4.6 V and 25 °C. However, it is still a challenge to improve the electrochemical performance of LiCoO2 at voltages higher than 4.60 V as well as the relatively higher temperature. Fluorine compounds have been studied to enhance the stability of cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries [28,29]. In particular, Kong et al. [30] synthesized MgF2-doped LiCoO2, showing the better retention of 80.8% after 500 cycles at 4.6 V, 1 C and room temperature. Aboulaich et al. [19] prepared CeF3-coated LiCoO2 via a co-precipitation tandem with solid state reaction, reporting that the modified material had better thermal stability with the discharge capacity of 160 mA h g−1 at 2.5–4.6 V (0.2 C), meanwhile the pristine LiCoO2 has 110 mA h g−1 at 2.5–4.6 V (0.2 C). In addition, cerium oxide fluoride (CeO1− x F1+2 x ) has been studied in catalysis and adsorption, owing to the fast electron and ion mobility as well as the superior oxygen storage capacity [31,32]. Cerium oxide has plenty of oxygen vacancies and can trap and store reactive oxygen [33,34]. Taking into account the desirable oxygen buffering property and the fast ion mobility characteristic of cerium oxide fluoride, in this work, we prepared Ce & F co-modified LiCoO2 by using the precursors of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and NH4F, and evaluated the electrochemical performance with the voltage greater than 4.60 V. At 3.0–4.60 V and 25 °C, the preferred sample LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F has a high initial discharge specific capacity of 221.9 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C, with the retention of 80.3% and 89.6% after 300 cycles at 1 and 5 C, versus the pristine LCO (56.4% and 22.6%). And at 3.0–4.65 V, its retention was 64.0% after 300 cycles at 1 C, versus 8.5% of the pristine LCO. Moreover at 3.0–4.60 V, 45 °C and 1 C, the retention of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F was 60.3% after 300 cycles, considerably superior to that of the pristine LCO (12.8%). Through structural characterizations and DFT calculations, it suggests that Ce4+ & F− co-doping suppresses the H3 to H1/3 irreversible structural transition, stabilizes the lattice structure, and reduces the redox activity of the lattice oxygen by regulating the Co 3d–O 2p energy band, consequently improving the electrochemical performance of LiCoO2 at high voltages. 2 Material synthesis The pristine LiCoO2 (denoted as LCO) was purchased from Shenzhen Kejing Zhida Technology Co. The individual Ce-modified sample (LCO-0.5Ce) and Ce & F co-modified sample (LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F) were prepared by the high-temperature solid phase method. The Ce-modified material was prepared by mixing 0.5 wt.% Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Macklin, 99.99%) with the pristine LiCoO2 powder of corresponding quality in an agate mortar. Added an appropriate amount of anhydrous ethanol to the mixture and grinded at room temperature for 30 min, followed by transferring it to 60 °C to evaporate the ethanol completely and the dry power was obtained. The mixture was calcined at 600 °C for 5 h in an air atmosphere with the heating rate of 5 °C min−1 and then cooled to room temperature at the same rate. The Ce-modified material was obtained, which was named LCO-0.5Ce. The Ce & F co-modified materials were prepared with the similar procedure. On the basis of 0.5 wt.% Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, the corresponding content of NH4F (Aladdin, 99.99%) was added in the atomic ratios of 1:2, 1:3 and 1:4 for the ratio of Ce and F, respectively, and then added LiCoO2 powder of corresponding mass. The subsequent steps are the same as the previous preparation process. The Ce & F co-modified materials were named according to the content of NH4F added, such as LCO-0.5Ce-0.2F, LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F and LCO-0.5Ce-0.4F, respectively. Using the same amount of F addition and similar procedure as those of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F sample, the individual F-modified sample LCO-0.3F was also prepared using NH4F as the precursor. 3 Results and discussion The electrochemical performance is tested (Fig. 1 a) at 3.0–4.60 V, 1 C (200 mA g−1) and 25 °C with 0.1 C for the initial two cycles. The initial discharge capacities at 0.1 C/1 C of the pristine LCO, LCO-0.5Ce, LCO-0.3F and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F samples are 215.7/199.1, 218.3/202.3, 217.6/196.1 and 221.9/201.0 mA h g−1, and the initial coulombic efficiencies (1 C) are 96.6%, 95.0%, 96.7% and 97.5%, which are increased obviously after Ce & F co-modification. The capacity retentions are 56.4%, 69.9%, 76.7% and 80.3% after 300 cycles (1 C) for LCO, LCO-0.5Ce, LCO-0.3F and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F, with 30.9%, 58.0%, 63.7% and 71.3% after 500 cycles (1 C). The cycling performances of other Ce & F co-modified samples are shown in Fig. S1(a). The charge and discharge plots (Fig. S1b–e) suggest that the pristine LCO shows severe degradation, corresponding to the large decay of the mid-point voltage of 0.3734 V over 500 cycles, while it reduces to 0.1574 V obviously for LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F (Fig. S1f). To evaluate the effect of Ce & F co-modification at higher cut-off voltage, the voltage is augmented to 4.65 V (Fig. 1b). The initial discharge capacity of LCO is 202.5 mA h g−1 at 1 C, but it decays rapidly to 17.2 mA h g−1 (8.5%) after 300 cycles, and the Coulombic efficiency fluctuates dramatically. For LCO-0.5Ce, the improvement of the cycling performance is not obvious, with the capacity retention of only 26.31% after 300 cycles (53.3 mA h g−1). Notably, through Ce & F co-modification, LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F exhibits quite excellent cycling performance with the highest initial discharge capacity of 204.3 mA h g−1 and the retention is 64.0% after 300 cycles. Furthermore, the discharge capacity of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F can remain 90.6 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles, superior to almost zero of LCO and LCO-0.5Ce. The Coulombic efficiency of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F also remains more stably, providing excellent cycling stability at the high voltage of 4.65 V. Table S1 lists the electrochemical performance of the related materials reported in recent literature, which indicates that Ce & F co-modified LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F is in the forefront. The rate performance (Fig. 1c) indicates that LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F has the highest discharge capacity of 223.6 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C and it also displays high capacities of 218.0, 207.7, 192.5, 172.2, 146.3 and 123.1 mA h g−1 at the rate of 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5 and 10 C (Table S2). Upon returning to 0.1 C, its discharge capacity exhibits the highest level of 209.9 mA h g−1. The cycling performance at 5 C (Fig. 1d) shows that the initial discharge capacity of the pristine LCO is 146.9 mA h g−1 and its retention diminishes to only 9.6% rapidly after 500 cycles. It is worth noting that, for LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F, the cycling stability at 5 C improves obviously with the highest initial capacity of 159.8 mA h g−1 (versus 158.4 mA h g−1 for LCO-0.5Ce) and it still delivers 128.4 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles with the retention as high as 80.4%, nearly twice that of LCO-0.5Ce (43.8%). The cycling performance at 45 °C (Fig. 1e) is tested at 3.0–4.60 V and 1 C. The initial capacity of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F significantly increases to 214.5 mA h g−1 (versus 206.5 mA h g−1 of LCO), and it also displays excellent cycling performance with the higher retention of 60.3% after 300 cycles, superior than 12.4% of LCO. The full-cell performance of LCO-Full and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F-Full at 3.0–4.60 V and 1 C are displayed in Fig. S2. The initial discharge capacity of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F-Full is 164.7 mA h g−1 (1 C), which is higher than LCO-Full (159.6 mA h g−1). After 300 cycles, the capacity retention of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F is 47.2%, versus 13.7% for LCO-Full. SEM images (Fig. S3) show that all samples display regular single crystal particles. The morphology and particle size do not change after modification except for the increased roughness, indicating changes of the composition on the surface of the materials. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) investigated the crystal structures of the pristine LCO, the individual Ce-modified sample (LCO-0.5Ce) and the Ce & F co-modified sample (LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F). Fig. 2 (a) shows that all samples feature the typical α-NaFeO2-type layered structure (JCPDF: 50-0653) with the space group of R-3m and (0 0 6)/(1 0 2) and (1 0 8)/(1 1 0) peaks show obvious peak splitting (Fig. S4a), indicating a highly ordered layered structure and good crystallinity [7]. Table 1 lays out the lattice parameters obtained from Rietveld refinement, corresponding to Fig. 2(b and c) and Fig. S4(b–d), with the values of c/a > 4.99 of all samples, indicating the ordered layered structure [35]. Comparing with the pristine LCO, the lattice parameters of a, c, V and the Li layer spacing I (Li layer) all become larger for all modified samples probably due to Ce4+ doping because of its larger ionic radius of r Ce 4+ = 0.87 Å versus r Co 3+ = 0.54 Å [23], and these values further increase with the adding amount of F, which probably associated with the effect of F ions on the Ce-doping into the inner lattice (Table S3, the lower surface content of Ce in LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F versus LCO-0.5Ce by XPS analysis), thus Ce & F co-modification can regulate the crystal structure more effectively. As shown in Fig. 2(d), the formation energy is calculated by DFT for Ce-doped at Co site and Ce & F co-doped at Co & O sites with three different F-doping sites (atomic configurations shown in Fig. S5). All substitutions lead to negative formation energy and when F replaces the lattice O attached with Ce (noted as LCO-Ce/F #1), the formation energy is the lowest, which is the most energetically favourable and the structural evolution by Ce & F co-doping displays in Fig. 2(e). HRTEM was carried out to investigate the surface microstructure and composition of LCO, LCO-0.5Ce and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F. In Fig. 2(f), the primary LCO displays a distinct feature with layered phase and the fast Fourier transform (FFT) pattern (Region 1) exhibits the lattice diffraction stripes of 0.468 nm belonging to the (0 0 3) plane of layered LiCoO2 (R-3m space group). However, HRTEM images of LCO-0.5Ce in Fig. 2(g) indicate the bulk structure does not change with clear layered structure (R-3m) and the lattice diffraction stripes of 0.207 nm belong to (1 0 4) plane. Differently, LCO-0.5Ce exhibits a surface coating layer (Region 3), which can be judged as CeO2 (JCPDF: 81-0792) (Fm-3m) with the lattice diffraction stripes of 0.314 nm associated with (1 1 1) plane [37]. Besides, in Fig. S6 (a), the FFT pattern (Region 1) indicates the formation of hexagonal phase Ce2O3 (P-3m) with the lattice stripes of 0.337 nm closed to (1 0 0) plane and a surface spinel phase (Fd-3m) forms (Region 2) with the FFT pattern indicating 0.208 nm lattice spacing of (4 0 0) plane, corresponding to spinel phase Co3O4 (JCPDF: 43-1003). The formation of the spinel-like phase may be due to the Ce4+/Ce3+ evolution, and the defective states and oxygen vacancies in CeO2− x would decrease the migration energy barrier of Co3+, thus causing changes in the surface microstructure [26]. For LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F, HRTEM images and FFT patterns (Fig. 2h) demonstrate that the bulk structure does no change with the increased distance of the lattice stripes of 0.482 nm associated with (0 0 3) plane of layered LiCoO2, indicating Ce4+ & F− co-dope into the lattice. However, the surface structure and composition have changed obviously with the multiphase heterostructure formed. The FFT pattern (Region 4) exhibits the formation of CeO2 phase (Fm-3m) with the 0.277 nm lattice spacing corresponding to the (2 0 0) plane, which is similar to the LCO-0.5Ce sample. Meanwhile, a new phase of CeOF solid solution is also found in LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F and the FFT pattern (Region 5) indicates the distance of the 0.334 and 0.329 nm lattice stripes closed to (0 0 6) and (1 0 2) planes of hexagonal phase CeOF (JCPDF:21-0183). Fig. S6(b) also indicates the presence of hexagonal phase CeF3 (P-3c1) with the lattice diffraction stripes of 0.256 and 0.206 nm belonging to (1 1 2) and (3 0 0) planes (JCPDF:38-0452). The multiphase heterostructure of CeO2− x and CeOF solid solution can suppress the harmful side reactions and mitigate the corrosion of HF, enabling the modified materials exhibit excellent cycling stability at high voltages. In addition, the EDS images (Fig. 2i and Fig. S7) show that Ce, F and other elements distribute uniformly on the surface of LiCoO2. XPS was employed to determine the surface constituents and oxidation states of elements. Ce 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 3 a) of LCO-0.5Ce and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F show the present of Ce4+ and Ce3+ with two spin-orbit splitting peaks of Ce 3d 5/2 and Ce 3d 3/2, where v and u represent their contributions respectively [38]. Three pairs of characteristic splitting peaks of Ce4+ are located at v/u≈882/901 eV, v″/u″≈889/907 eV and v‴/u‴≈898/917 eV corresponding to three different electron configurations of Ce 3d 9 4f 2–O 2p 4, Ce 3d 9 4f 1–O 2p 5 and Ce 3d 9 4f0–O 2p 6, and two pairs of characteristic splitting peaks for Ce3+ located at v 0/u 0≈880/897 eV and v′/u′≈885/903 eV corresponding to Ce 3d 9 4f 2–O 2p 5 and Ce 3d 9 4f 1–O 2p 6 [26,39], as shown in Table S4. The results suggest CeO2− x exists in the modified samples of LCO-0.5Ce and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F. During the process of high-temperature annealing for material preparation, parts of CeO2 would be reduced into CeO2− x [40], which has more Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies and enhances the ability to store and release oxygen ions reversibly [34,41]. For LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F, the binding energy of Ce3+ increased obviously after F− added. The two peaks at v 0≈886.77 eV and u 0≈904.80 eV correspond to CeF bonds [42], confirming the existence of CeF3 or CeOF. The peaks located at v′≈884.15 eV and u′≈902.14 eV of Ce3+also shift towards higher binding energy obviously. The XPS spectra of F 1s (Fig. 3b) also indicate the peak of CeF bonds at 684.65 eV [43] with the LiF peak (LiF bonds) located at 685.34 eV [44]. Due to the similar ionic radius of F− (r F − = 1.33 Å) and O2− (r O 2− = 1.40 Å) [11] but higher electronegativity of F−, some F− tends to replace the lattice O near Ce dopants, forming stronger CeF bonds, and the formation of CeOF solid solution probably comes from the F− doping. The relative content of Ce and F in LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F at different etching time shows in Fig. 3(c) and Table S5. Ce and F can still be detected at the etching time of 250 s, and with the increasing of etching time, a slight decrease in Ce content occurs, while the content of F decreases obviously, demonstrating F is more enriched in the surface region, while Ce doping is more uniform in LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F. Due to spin-orbit coupling, Co 2p peaks (Fig. 3d) split into two main peaks of Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 with the binding energy approximate of 780.00 and 795.00 eV and two satellites [45]. The peak fitting of main peaks reveals the presence of Co3+ and Co2+, with Co2+ having a higher binding energy than Co3+. Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 peaks shift towards higher binding energy with the increased relative content of Co2+ in both LCO-0.5Ce and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F (Table S6). Through DFT calculations, Bader charge analysis (Fig. 3e) shows the doping of Ce and F resulting in the charge state of surrounding Co ions changing obviously. Ce doping individually causes charge increased of the surrounding Co ions, while Ce & F co-doping further leads to the acquisition of more electrons by parts of Co ions, probably due to Ce4+ and F− participated in the charge compensation together to re-achieve charge equilibrium [25], leading to the decrease in the oxidation state of Co ions [46] and the shift of Co XPS peaks [47]. The spinel phase Co3O4 formed in LCO-0.5Ce can also increase the Co2+ content [48], aligned with the HRTEM analysis. The O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. S8a) show peaks at 529.50 eV (lattice oxygen), 531.70 eV (oxygen vacancies) and 532.60 eV (adsorbed oxygen) [49]. The highest content of surface oxygen vacancies in LCO-0.5Ce (Table S7) is due to CeO2− x species [23] and the content has decreased in LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F probably due to F− doping. In LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F, the peak of lattice oxygen shifts to higher binding energy with higher relative content of 64.71% versus 47.15% for the pristine LCO, indicating the lattice oxygen is stabilized due to stronger CeO bonds (E (Ce−O) = 795 kJ mol−1 > E (Co−O) = 321 kJ mol−1) [45,50]. However, the surface adsorbed oxygen reduced to 6.16% versus 14.12% for the pristine LCO, which is because the multiphase heterostructure strengthens the surface structural stability and inhibits the generation of Li2CO3 and LiOH associated with surface adsorbed oxygen [24,33], thus mitigating the harmful impact due to the decomposition of electrolytes [37]. To disclose the efficacy of Ce & F co-doping on the structural and electronic properties of LiCoO2, the length of CoO bonds (Fig. 3f) and the density of states (DOS) (Fig. 3g) are analysed. The initial LCO has typical semiconductor characteristics, showing a large band gap of 2.33 eV near the Fermi energy level, and it significantly reduces to 1.14 eV in LCO-Ce/F #1, which can increase the electronic conductivity and contribute to fast charge transfer kinetics [30,51]. Meanwhile, the energy gap of Co 3d–O 2p band centers (PDOS) increases from 1.3030 eV (LCO) to 1.5079 eV (LCO-Ce/F #1), indicating the lower redox activity of the lattice oxygen after Ce & F co-doping, thus enhancing the ionicity of CoO bonds and reducing proportions of lattice oxygen to participate in charge compensation at high voltages [52], which is corresponding to the increased length of CoO bonds (Fig. 3f). In addition, the Li layer spacing calculated increases from 2.648 Å (LCO) to 2.654 Å (LCO-Ce) and further to 2.657 Å of LCO-Ce/F #1 by Ce & F co-doping, thus accelerating the diffusion of Li+, coincident with the XRD Rietveld refinement. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests (Fig. 4 a and b, Fig. S10) were performed for LCO, LCO-0.5Ce and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F samples (scanning rate of 0.1 mV s−1). The redox peaks in CV tests relate to the structure transition during charging/discharging processes. The oxidation peaks around 4.02, 4.09 and 4.19 V and reduction peaks around 3.86, 4.05 and 4.15 V are corresponding to the phase changes of hexagonal phase H1 to H2, H2 to monoclinic phase M1, and M1 to H3. The highest oxidation peak represents the oxidation reaction between Co3+ and Co4+. The oxidation peak close to 4.55 V correlates with the H3–M2 phase transition [27]. Therefore, LiCoO2 exhibits as H1/3 phase (a mixed phase of H3+M2) at 4.60 V. As the voltage increases, the deeper de-lithiation state causes the rearrangement of the lattice oxygen, and when the Li ions are completely removed, the structure of LiCoO2 will be transformed into the O1 phase [53], which is irreversible completely. The oxidation peak around 4.09 V is distinctly visible in pristine LCO, indicating the H2–M1 transition occurs obviously. However, in LCO-0.5Ce and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F, this peak is weakened, probably because the highest oxidation peak has shifted to the higher voltage and the peak shape is broadened with two peaks merging into a single main peak near 4.04 V, exhibiting a more stable peak current [54], which is particularly obvious in LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F, suggesting Ce & F co-modification can modulate the surface potential of the electrode, making the modified material more resistant to electrochemical oxidation [55]. The potential difference ( Δ V) between the main redox peaks indicates the degree of polarisation of the electrode [48,56]. In the initial cycle, the potential difference of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F is 0.212 V, lower than that of the pristine LCO ( Δ V = 0.220 V), but slightly higher than that of LCO-0.5Ce ( Δ V = 0.205 V) (Fig. S10), probably due to the formation of LiF on its surface (Fig. 3b, XPS peak of LiF) and more activation processes are needed. Thus, Ce & F co-modification reduces the polarisation of the electrode and improves the reversibility of the structure, which is compatible with its superior electrochemical performance at high voltage. In situ XRD tests (Fig. 4c and d) were carried out for pristine LCO and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F at 3.0–4.60 V and 0.2 C. During the initial charging stage (≈3.9 V), the splitting of (0 0 3) and (1 0 7) peaks is correlated with the insulator–metal transition (H1–H2); at approximately 4.1 V, the shift of the (0 0 3) peak and the splitting of the (1 0 7) peak correspond to the H2–M1 (ordered-disordered) transition; beyond 4.2 V, the monoclinic phase M1 reverts to the hexagonal phase H3; while charging to near 4.6 V, the (0 0 3) peak shifts substantially, relating to the transition of H3–H1/3 [45,57], which are coincident with the results of CV tests. The position evolution of (0 0 3) peak represents the change of the lattice parameter c [58]. During the initial charging stage, along with the remove of Li+, the Coulombic repulsive force between adjacent OCoO layers becomes larger [57], causing the c-axis to increase; while as the voltage continues to increase, the deep de-lithiation leads to the slip of the OCoO layers [59], causing the value of c decreased. Therefore, the c-axis suffers continuous expansion and contraction and the internal stresses accumulated, leading to microcracks formed or even pulverization of the particles eventually after long-term cycling. For pristine LCO, the peak position of (0 0 3) shows a larger evolution (1.34°), while for LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F it is significantly weakened (1.16°), demonstrating the H3 to H1/3 irreversible phase transition is suppressed by Ce & F co-modification. The electrochemical impedance (EIS) tests were performed to analyze the interfacial resistance of the electrode. The Nyquist plots and fitting results at different cycles of all samples exhibit in Fig. S11(a–c) and Table S8. Fig. 5 (a and b) compares the impedance results of each sample at the 1st and 300th cycles. In each Nyquist plot, extend the Nyquist plots in the opposite direction and the intersection point with the x-axis is the ohmic impedance (R s); the semicircle in the high and mid frequency regions are the electrode/electrolyte interface impedance (R f) and the charge transfer impedance of the electrodes (R ct); the sloping line in the low frequency region is the Warburg impedance (W 0), corresponding to the solid state diffusion of Li+ [23]. The values of R s and R f vary slightly along cycling, but R ct shows a significant increase (Fig. 5c), which is the key factor that limits the electrochemical properties, and is used to characterize the ion transport kinetics at the interface [48]. After the 1st cycle, the R ct of LCO-0.5Ce and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F is marginally higher than that of LCO, perhaps because of the formation of the CeO2− x as well as the CeOF solid solution on the surface. After 300 cycles, the R ct of LCO raises from 16.81 to 447.7 Ω in increments of 430.89 Ω, and for LCO-0.5Ce, it raises from 18.50 to 320.80 Ω in increments of 302.30 Ω. While for LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F, the R ct increases from 27.40 to 180.50 Ω in increments of only 153.10 Ω. The growth of R ct is suppressed, suggesting the multiphase heterostructure can stabilize the structure of the cathode and resist the corrosion of HF originated from electrolyte decomposition [26]. CV tests with different scanning rates were carried out (Fig. S11d–f) to determine the D Li + of each sample during de-lithiation and lithiation. It can be calculated by the Randles-Sevcik’s law, the linear fit of the peak current I p with the scan rate1/2 exhibits in Fig. 5(d), indicating these processes are controlled by Li+ solid-state diffusion [46]. The Randles-Sevcik equation can be written as [26] (1) I p = 2.69 × 10 5 × n 3 / 2 × A × D 1 / 2 × υ 1 / 2 × C 0 where I p denotes the peak current, n is the number of electron transfers in the electrochemical reaction (n = 1), A is the area of the electrode sheet, D is the Li+ diffusion coefficient, υ is the scan rate of CV tests, and C 0 is the concentration of Li+ in the material. Corresponding D Li + values of LCO, LCO-0.5Ce and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F are listed in Table 2 . Compared to pristine LCO and LCO-0.5Ce, the D Li + of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F is the highest. GITT tests (Fig. 5e and f) were also carried out on all samples in the initial cycle and after 100 cycles to further explore the Li+ diffusion coefficient (D Li +) in the discharge process. The original test curves and detail calculation processes show in the Supporting Information (Fig. S12). The results exhibit the D Li + of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F is significantly higher than that of the pristine LCO both in the initial cycle and after 100 cycles. It can be attributed to the expanded lattice spacing by Ce4+ & F− co-doping and the multiphase heterostructure of CeO2− x and CeOF solid solution, which enhance the surface and interface structure of the cathode, thus accelerating the diffusion of Li+ [33]. Fig. 6 (a) displays the XRD patterns of LCO, LCO-0.5Ce and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F after 500 cycles. For LCO, the shift of the (0 0 3) peak is 0.16°, indicating significant expansion of the c-axis [9,60] and the continuous irreversible phase transitions during cycling results in the lattice distortion. However, for LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F, the shift of the (0 0 3) peak reduces to only 0.08°, much smaller than that of LCO, suggesting the irreversible phase transitions is inhibited and the stability of the structure has improved [45]. After 500 cycles, SEM images of the spent LCO (Fig. 6b and Fig. S13a) exhibit severe disintegration with deep cracks, providing a channel for the corrosion of the electrolyte into the interior structure of the material, which will further accelerate the structure degradation, whereas the spent LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F (Fig. 6c and Fig. S13b) maintains tight and intact spherical particles. Fig. 6(d and e) show the HRTEM images of spent LCO and LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F after 500 cycles. The spent LCO (Fig. 6d) shows that the previous layered structure has disappeared clearly and it forms a large area of spinel-like phase Co3O4 (Fd-3m space group) (Region 1) from the edge to the inner bulk structure, which will inhibit the diffusion of Li+. At high voltages, the oxidation of oxygen ions occurs along with the release of O2, while Co3+ is continuously reduced and migrates out of the structure causing Co dissolution, leading to severe irreversible phase transitions and lattice collapse [61]. However, the structure of LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F (Fig. 6e) still remains layered LiCoO2 (R-3m space group) after 500 cycles, with the lattice diffraction stripes of 0.468, 0.249 and 0.207 nm aligned with (0 0 3), (1 0 1) and (1 0 4) planes (Region 2). Furthermore, the multiphase heterostructure is still clearly visible, indicating the good chemical stability and interfacial compatibility during cycling, containing the rock-salt phase CeO2 (Region 3) with the 0.317 nm lattice spacing belonging to the (1 1 1) plane and the hexagonal phase CeOF solid solution (Region 4) showing the lattice diffraction stripes of 0.323 and 0.215 nm approximating its (1 0 2) and (1 0 8) planes. At high voltages, Co3+ is continuously reduced and migrates out of the structure causing Co dissolved on the Li anode (Fig. S14), and the content of Co element on each Li anode is tested by ICP (Table 3 ), which indicates that Co dissolution is suppressed obviously after Ce & F co-modification and the multiphase heterostructure can protect the surface of LCO effectively. Therefore, after Ce & F co-modification, Ce4+ & F− co-doping suppresses the H3 to H1/3 irreversible structural transition and improves the structural stability; the multiphase heterostructure of CeO2− x and CeOF solid solution phase adheres firmly with LiCoO2 during cycling, which is resistant to the corrosion of HF, thus keeping the integrity of the cathode. Consequently, the Ce & F co-modified sample LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F has superior cycling stability and higher rate performance than the pristine LCO and LCO-0.5Ce modified by Ce individually. 4 Conclusions In this work, the Ce & F co-modified LiCoO2 was prepared by a solid-phase method using Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and NH4F as precursors. The results indicate that Ce4+ & F− co-doping enlarges the lattice parameters, promotes the diffusion of Li+ and suppresses the H3 to H1-3 irreversible phase transition, thus enhancing the structural stability. In addition, DFT calculations indicate that Ce4+ & F− co-doping changes the electronic structure of the material, reduces the band gap from 2.33 to 1.14 eV with higher electronic conductivity and increases the energy gap of Co 3d and O 2p from 1.3030 to 1.5079 eV with lower redox activity of lattice oxygen, stabilizing the lattice oxygen at high voltage. In particular, the Ce & F co-modified material has a multiphase heterostructure containing surface CeO2− x and new CeOF solid solution phase, mitigating the interface side reactions and suppressing the growth of charge transfer impedance. At 3.0–4.60 V and 25 °C, the preferred sample LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F obtains an initial discharge capacity of 221.9 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C, with the capacity retention of 80.3% (1 C) and 89.6% (5 C) after 300 cycles respectively, versus 56.4% and 22.6% of the pristine LCO; moreover, at 3.0–4.65 V and 1 C, it displays the more outstanding capacity retention of 64.0% after 300 cycles, versus 8.5% of the pristine LCO. And at 3.0–4.60 V, 45 °C and 1 C, its initial discharge capacity is 214.5 mA h g−1 with the retention of 60.3% after 300 cycles, comparing with 12.8% of the pristine LCO. This work demonstrates the co-effect of structure regulation and surface engineering by Ce & F co-modification for LiCoO2, significantly improving the electrochemical performance beyond 4.60 V, which can provide a meaningful reference for the design of cathode materials for high-voltage lithium cobalt oxide. coredata.dc:description: Lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO2) is proverbially employed as cathode materials of lithium-ion batteries attributed to the high theoretical capacity, and currently, it is developing towards higher cut-off voltages in the pursuit of higher energy density. However, it suffers from serious structural degradation and surface side reactions, in particular, at the voltage above 4.60 V, leading to rapid decay of the battery life. Taking into account the desirable oxygen buffering property and the fast ion mobility characteristic of cerium oxide fluoride, in this work, we prepared Ce & F co-modified LiCoO2 by using the precursors of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and NH4F, and evaluated the electrochemical performance under voltages exceeding 4.60 V. The results indicated that the modified samples have multiphase heterostructure of surface CeO2− x and unique CeOF solid solution phase. At 3.0–4.60 V and 25 °C, the preferred sample LCO-0.5Ce-0.3F has a high initial discharge specific capacity of 221.9 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C, with the retention of 80.3% and 89.6% after 300 cycles at 1 and 5 C, comparing with the pristine LCO (56.4% and 22.6%). And at 3.0–4.65 V, its retention is 64.0% after 300 cycles at 1 C, versus 8.5% of the pristine LCO. Through structural characterizations and DFT calculations, it suggests that Ce4+ & F− co-doping suppresses the H3 to H1/3 irreversible phase transition, stabilizes the lattice structure, and reduces the redox activity of the lattice oxygen by modulating the Co 3d–O 2p energy band, consequently improving the electrochemical performance of LiCoO2 at high voltages.
